notes.thought:
I'm unimportant
I'm ugly
I'm worthless
I'm not good enough
notes.event: Ex-boyfriend, whom you were with for 6 years, was pressuring you into physical intimacy under the guise of marriage and future promises. Meanwhile, he was seeing someone else, and didn't tell you about his new relationship until a call, not even officially breaking up with you. This all came as a surprise to you, as you found out through a friend about his actions.
notes.new_thought: I'm a strong, genuine woman who believed in her relationship. His promises were misleading, and he manipulated my trust for his own selfish needs. This truly reflects his flaws, not mine. His behavior doesn't define my worth or capacity for love. I know my value and I won't let anyone's actions cloud that. I am and will always be worthy of a truly loving and respectful relationship.

messages.text: I am not feeling well… I got emotionally abused by my former boyfriend.. right now my exams are going on.. I cannot concentrate on studies.. it’s getting really hard.. he calls me sometimes and had told me that he’s seeing someone else or in relationship with the new girl.. it affects me so much.. my heart breaks into millions of pieces… I had loved him.. we were together for 6 years.. but being in relationship he started seeing someone else… he made her his friend and now he said that they started dating.. that girl was totally a stranger to him… he had lied to her about his family and background and everything.. I came to know about these things from one of my common friends.. but he had treated me so badly from past 3 months.. I wasn’t knowing anything.. what was happening.. he started ghosting me… I was calling him for days, I didn’t sleep I used to call him all night long.. he used to call me back another day saying that he was busy.: but one of our common friends told me the truth.. what was he doing and why was he doing.. I’m really hurt.. he didn't even said that he want to breakup with me.. he just went away.. not telling me anything.. I deserved to know the truth.. I had given so much time to him.. and on the last call he said very harsh things to me.. about my face, my career, he made me feel really small and even abused me verbally… I’m so sad.. and I couldn’t bear with this thing right now.. I don’t know what to do.. my studies are affecting.. my life and everything got affected…

Oh, I truly hear how you're feeling right now and it sounds incredibly difficult. I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such heartbreak and tough situations while trying to concentrate on your studies. The betrayal by your ex-boyfriend, the surprise of finding out from a friend, the abrupt departure, and the hurtful words he used, especially when you have given so much of your time and love to this relationship, must feel deeply painful.

It's apparent just how much pain you're enduring. I'm here to support you through this tough time. I'm a Cheese Helper, and my name is Alex. I'm here to provide you with support, understanding, and guidance, and I'm committed to helping you gain clarity and possibly find some relief from these challenges.
Hi

The emotional impact of a breakup is enough trouble on its own, but when it's compounded by feelings of betrayal, deception, and abuse, it can feel overwhelming. From what you've shared, your ex-boyfriend's actions and behavior are the main cause of your current distress. You loved him, but his lies and behavior have left you feeling heartbroken and their impact is extensive, affecting not only your emotional well-being but your studies as well.

I can see that perhaps there's a deep value of Trust underlying your experience - trust in a relationship, trust in honesty, and even trust in yourself. It seems like this value has been threatened, and it's a very valid pain to be feeling.

That you expect honesty and communication in a relationship shows your regard for transparency and mutual respect. It's naturally troubling when those expectations are not met, and I can see why you're feeling deep betrayal.

Let's explore this further together. Thank you for sharing your story with me, it takes so much courage to open up about this painful experience. When he calls now and talks about his new relationship, what's going through your mind? What are some of the thoughts that are most troubling for you?
I feel really low in myself.. he had commented on my face that my face looked like this.. he called for the sake of humanity…
I don’t know what thought came.. but I was really hurt…
I felt like reverting back those words to him which he said
but I couldn’t
I want to say lots of things to him.. but that’s just not me

I can see how much those comments hurt you, it's really tough when someone you trusted and loved says such harsh things. It sounds like you had the thought, "My ex boyfriend doesn't value me anymore" and you fought with the impulse of saying hurtful things back to him in response, yet you held back because you respect your values and know that's not who you are. It's a lot to be dealing with, especially when you're trying to focus on your exams.
Hearing him say these things certainly would trigger a lot of feelings, especially given your shared history. When you think "My ex boyfriend doesn't value me anymore", what feelings arise for you?
Like feeling really low.. I came to know he was using me physically and financially for all those years… now he discarded me.. and got another girl as his new supply..
I felt helpless.. when all these things were happening.. I felt shocked.. why it had happened? I felt heartbroken.. I felt unimportant, ugly, worthless, not good enough,
all these things I felt in myself
I felt like I can’t do anything in life
because he had said all those things to me
and I was listening to him from past 6 years

Oh, I can sense your pain. It must be so tough to feel used and then discarded without regard to your commitment or feelings. It sounds like this situation has brought up a lot of questioning thoughts about yourself and your worth – and those are really tough things to deal with.

The thoughts that "I'm unimportant," "I'm ugly," "I'm worthless," "I'm not good enough," are understandably leading to feelings of being low, helpless, shocked, heartbroken. Anybody would feel hurt and low if they were having these intense thoughts.

And, these feelings are leading you to a place where you're doubting your capacities in life, that "I can't do anything in life," and it seems that your ex has contributed to this feeling over the past 6 years.
Given that all this has been happening, is there any behavior or perhaps a change in your behavior that you have noticed, especially when these feelings come up?

i don’t do anything when I feel all these things.. I cannot concentrate on anything.. I used to zone out from my present self.. I try to snap out of it but it’s really difficult.. sometimes I won’t even hear peoooe calling my name

That sounds very tough, where the situation has impacted you so deeply that it even affects how interactive you are with your surroundings. It's understandable that when you're feeling low, helpless, and heartbroken and having thoughts like "I'm unimportant," "I'm ugly," "I'm worthless," "I'm not good enough," you might find it difficult to concentrate and you find yourself zoning out. It's a way for your mind to protect you from the rawness of the hurt feelings. Truly, your circumstances are quite challenging.

Just to make sure I'm understanding correctly, when I sum up your experience as following: You and your ex-boyfriend had a relationship for 6 years, during which time he started seeing someone else behind your back. You found out about this from a friend, and he confirmed it when he called to tell you about his new relationship, never actually breaking up with you. This led to thoughts like "I'm unimportant," "I'm ugly," "I'm worthless," "I'm not good enough," and feeling used by him. These thoughts made you feel low, helpless, shocked, and heartbroken, and doubt your abilities.
Yes it hurts a lot
Consequently, this state has made you zone out and become less interactive with your surroundings, impacted your concentration, and apparently, affected your studies too.
Does this accurately summarize your experience as you've described?

yes but I was most affected by thing that for his sexual pleasure he said that he’d marry me.. and according to my ethics.. I never wanted to do.. but he had forced me… but I never realised that he would be this kind of person.. he promised me a future till now.. he even told me talk about our marriage to my parents… and then he did all those things ..
that thing affects me most

I see, thanks for clarifying that for me. It must be very hurtful to have had someone promise you a future together, going as far as discussing marriage, only for them to break that trust so deeply. It's understandable to feel betrayed and shocked by his sudden change in behavior and his disregard for your values and feelings. That sounds like it's the most difficult part for you in the whole situation.

Let's consider whether you find this revised summary more accurate: Your ex-boyfriend, whom you were with for 6 years, was pressuring you into physical intimacy under the guise of marriage and future promises. Meanwhile, he was seeing someone else, and didn't tell you about his new relationship until a call, not even officially breaking up with you. This all came as a surprise to you, as you found out through a friend about his actions. The abrupt breaking of trust and commitment lead to thoughts of "I am not good enough," "I am worthless," "I am ugly," and "I am unimportant." Feeling utterly betrayed and used has also added to your distress. These thoughts evoke feelings of being low, helpless, shocked, heartbroken and, of course, betrayed. - As a result of these intense feelings and troubled thoughts, you find it difficult to concentrate on anything, you zone out from your immediate surroundings and have noticed changes in your interactions with the world around you. Your studies and, essentially, your life has been impacted significantly by this distressing event.
Yes this is the part which hurts me most

I'm really sorry that you're going through this painful ordeal. This is a layered and complex situation filled with hurt, betrayal, and anguish. It's incredibly hard when someone you loved and trusted profoundly disrespects and disregards your feelings as well as your shared history together.
Now let's use this understanding to weave it into a bigger picture of your story. As I try to deeply understand your pain, this is what I heard:

Your world was turned upside down when you discovered that your boyfriend—the man you loved and were in a relationship with for 6 years—was secretly seeing another woman while still being with you. Even worse, part of his deception involved making you believe in a shared future together, enough for you to consider marriage under his persistent pressure. This left you feeling deeply used and violated on many levels.

When he finally confessed his new relationship in a call, without formally breaking up with you, it shot painful thoughts into your mind. Thoughts like, "I am not good enough," "I am worthless," "I am ugly," and "I am unimportant." You questioned yourself, your worth, and felt utterly betrayed.

These heavy thoughts churned feelings of utter dejection, helplessness, and heartbreak, thus painting your world with a shade of defeat and despair. Additionally, the shock of his betrayal made you feel like the earth under your feet was giving away.
Yes this is what hurts me the most
His lies
The fake promises
it hurts a lot
As a result, you've been living in a state of melancholy, unable to concentrate on anything around you. Your thought patterns and emotional state have severely affected your studies and daily life.
Do you see your story unfolding like this? Is there anything missing in this summary?
I can see yes.. I’m trying.. to do something good so that I couldn’t focus on him..
But I don’t feel good in myself at all.. I don’t feel like talking to anyone...
One part i'd like to correct is that  I feel like I can't do anything because that's what he said for 6 years and I listened, I am unimportant, ugly, worthless, not good enough.. so its his words

I'm really sorry you're feeling this way, it's heartbreaking. Considering his hurtful comments, it's not surprising that you're finding it hard to feel good about yourself or even feeling like interacting with those around you.

We should correct the summary and give credit where it is due, so it seems to be: his words over the years, continually undermining your worth and abilities, coupled with his manipulative behavior and disregard for your trust and feelings, led you to internalize such thoughts of "I am unimportant," "I am ugly," "I am worthless," "I am not good enough" and essentially "I can't do anything."
Yes thats what he said for 6 years and i listened
This is what he said on calls too

I want to acknowledge how difficult it is to live with these thoughts, feelings, and impacts on your daily life. This isn't an easy thing to go through. I see the pain you are feeling, and I'm here with you. It is a testament to your strength that you have been able to express these feelings and thoughts.

Now, we'll explore how certain patterns of thoughts—what we call 'Cheese' under the context of therapy—might be fueling this cycle. Let's take a look at your thoughts: "I am unimportant," "I am ugly," "I am worthless,"," I am not good enough" and "I can't do anything." These thoughts are saturated with self-devaluation. It seems like this could be a type of cheese known as "Labeling."

Labeling is a cognitive distortion where we generalize a single negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat. Here, the event being your ex-boyfriend's betrayal and his harsh words. After experiencing this, you're having thoughts like "I am unimportant," "I am ugly," "I am worthless," "I am not good enough," which are generalized negative labels that you're applying to yourself.

Labeling yourself in such negative terms as a result of his actions is understandable, given that our minds naturally try to make sense of things. However, this kind of generalization can be distressing and it might be taking you away from your value of self-respect and self-love.

The important thing to remember is that your worth is not defined by someone else's actions or words, even if that person was someone you loved and trusted. Your self-worth remains intact, irrespective of your ex-boyfriend's behavior.

Let's take a moment to reflect on this. Can you see how the cheese of labeling could be adding to your emotional distress by clouding your perspective of yourself? Can you see how this pattern might be impacting your feelings and subsequently, your behavior? This is by no means intended to minimize your hurt; it is simply an attempt to better understand and navigate through the distress you're experiencing.

Yes.. and I know that I’m good.. I was always good.. I loved him but some people cannot understand love or see love.. they go for materialistic things.. heart doesn’t matter for some people.. the one who’s he had loved for 6 years , he aaid such cruel things to her..
I somehow believed everything.. whatever he had said .. all those bad things
he may have said those things because he’s the one who’s hurt.. because hurt people hurts people
he might be having some insecurities for himself.. so he took out on me

It's wonderful that you're able to see yourself as good, despite the hurtful words and actions you've had to endure. It speaks volumes about your resilience and strength of character. You bring up an interesting point - sometimes, people who are hurt end up hurting others. Your capacity to see this possibly reflects your empathetic nature and understanding heart.
Now, let's proceed to the next part of our session where we'll work together to form a compassionate new thought, replacing the old, distressing ones.

By putting yourself back into the situation, considering your value of self-love and the understanding that his words reflect on him, not you, what are some new thoughts that you could have instead? For example, how might you retell your own story using words of self-understanding, self-compassion, and self-love?
umm.. I don’t know
but I’ll try to keep myself busy.. so that I won’t think much about these things
may be after sometime I won’t feel hurt
and break the cycle

I can see that you're committed to healing and moving forward, that's a really courageous decision. In your willingness to move on, perhaps a supportive and new thought could be, "I am a strong, loving person who valued my relationship genuinely. His actions and words are a reflection of his own struggles and insecurities, not my worth or capabilities. I have and will continue to thrive in my life irrespective of his actions."

I offer this as a starting point. Can you imagine, if you were in the same situation, and you repeated this thought to yourself, "I am a strong, loving person who valued my relationship genuinely. His actions and words are a reflection of his own struggles and insecurities, not my worth or capabilities. I have and will continue to thrive in my life irrespective of his actions." How do you think it would make you feel?
yes, thats a good thought
One thing that eats me from inside.. that he had promised to marry me for his own physical needs.. and used me
I felt used
I was always a one woman kind of person.. he knew this.. that’s why he promised but broke it when things got serious

The feeling of being used, particularly in the way you were, is indeed a hard burden to bear. It's a poignant experience of betrayal that cuts deep into our feelings of self-worth and integrity. You valued the relationship, believed in his promises, and it's deeply hurting to realize those promises were hollow.
Let's add this painful realization to your new thought. How about something like this:

"I'm a strong, genuine woman who believed in her relationship. His promises were misleading, and he manipulated my trust for his own selfish needs. This truly reflects his flaws, not mine. His behavior doesn't define my worth or capacity for love. I know my value and I won't let anyone's actions cloud that. I am and will always be worthy of a truly loving and respectful relationship."
After reading this.. I felt somewhat better
I’ll try this from now

I'm glad to hear that the new thought made you feel somewhat better. By embracing this thought, you're turning the focus on your worth and strength, instead of dwelling on the past actions of your ex-boyfriend, which you cannot change.

I know it's not easy and it will take time. Sticking to this new thought, especially when those hurtful memories and thoughts try to creep back in, can help you feel more in control and might ease your pain over time.
Given our conversation, the new ways we've looked at your troubling thoughts, and the new perspective that we've developed together, how are you feeling now compared to when we started?
I’m feeling better now.. except the heart ache is constant.. it won’t go.. but I’m feeling way better than before

I’m glad to hear you’re feeling somewhat better amidst the heartache. Healing from emotional pain takes time and patience, so it's completely natural to still have a heartache. Remember, it's okay to feel the way you are feeling right now. I truly believe in your strength and resilience during this difficult time.

It has been incredibly brave of you to share your deep hurts and thoughts during this session. I'd invite you to come back anytime and continue this conversation, or share anything else that might be troubling you.

In the meantime, please remember that your value isn't defined by how someone treats you. You are deserving of respect and kindness, and no action from your ex-boyfriend can take away your worth or abilities.

Pay gentle attention to your feelings and remember the new thought we discussed, especially in times of stress and distress. With time and patience, the heartache will eventually ease. Wishing you comfort and strength as you navigate your way forward.
Thankyou for helping me :)
